title: Using expsmooth: worked examples
text: package contains collection datasets designed accompany book “Forecasting Exponential Smoothing: State Space Approach” Rob J Hyndman, Anne B Koehler, J Keith Ord, Ralph D Snyder (Springer, 2008). book can purchased .  expsmooth package loaded, forecast package also loaded, providing functions fit forecast exponential smoothing state space models. vignette replicate Section 2.8 book, provide worked solutions exercises Section 2.9. forecast package updated since book published, resulting model estimates may different book. Figure numbers taken book.

title: Using expsmooth: worked examples
text: graph time series often exhibits patterns, upward downward movement (trend) pattern repeats (seasonal variation), might used forecast future values. Chapters 1 2 reference four data sets included expsmooth package. bonds: 125 monthly US government bond yields (percent per annum) January 1994 May 2004. usnetelec: 55 observations annual US net electricity generation (billion kwh) 1949 2003. ukcars: 113 quarterly observations passenger motor vehicle production UK (thousands cars) first quarter 1977 first quarter 2005. visitors: 240 monthly observations number short term overseas visitors Australia May 1985 April 2005. time series shown Figure 1.1 reproduced :
code: library(expsmooth) library(ggplot2) library(patchwork) plot_bonds <- autoplot(bonds) +   labs(     title = "(a) US 10-year Bonds Yield",     x = "Year",     y = "Percentage per Annum"   ) plot_usnetelec <- autoplot(usnetelec) +   labs(     title = "(b) US Net Electricity Generation",     x = "Year",     y = "Billion kWh"   ) plot_ukcars <- autoplot(ukcars) +   labs(     title = "(c) UK Passenger Vehicle Production",     x = "Year",     y = "Thousands of Cars"   ) plot_visitors <- autoplot(visitors) +   labs(     title = "(d) Overseas Visitors to Australia",     x = "Year",     y = "Thousands of People"   ) (plot_bonds | plot_usnetelec) /   (plot_ukcars | plot_visitors)

title: Using expsmooth: worked examples
text: part vignette follow methodology described Section 2.8 book, reproduce results reported . also provides answers Exercise 2.3 Exercise 2.4. estimation model selection performed ets() function forecasting done forecast() function. part forecast package. basic introduction using functions given Section 7.6 Section 7.7 “Forecasting: Principles Practice” George Athanasopoulos Rob J. Hyndman. automatic forecasting process carried four data sets. process explained first data set, relevant results reported others.

title: Using expsmooth: worked examples
text: ets() function used apply appropriate models (optimising parameters case), also selects best model according AICc. AICc default penalised likelihood, others can specified. autoplot() function can used show states time.  forecast() function used produce point forecasts prediction intervals. summary() function called forecast object, prints model information along point forecasts prediction intervals. autoplot() function can called forecast object produce graph shown Figure 2.1.
code: fit_bonds <- ets(bonds) summary(fit_bonds) #> ETS(A,Ad,N)  #>  #> Call: #> ets(y = bonds) #>  #>   Smoothing parameters: #>     alpha = 0.9999  #>     beta  = 0.0954  #>     phi   = 0.8026  #>  #>   Initial states: #>     l = 5.3252  #>     b = 0.5934  #>  #>   sigma:  0.2428 #>  #>      AIC     AICc      BIC  #> 256.5383 257.2502 273.5082  #>  #> Training set error measures: #>                       ME      RMSE       MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set -0.01622111 0.2378765 0.1969524 -0.3276314 3.611147 0.2440042 #>                   ACF1 #> Training set 0.1426552 autoplot(fit_bonds) #> Warning in fortify(data, ...): Arguments in `...` must be used. #> ✖ Problematic argument: #> • ylab = "" #> ℹ Did you misspell an argument name? #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the forecast package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/robjhyndman/forecast/issues>. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated. forecast_bonds <- forecast(fit_bonds, level = 80) summary(forecast_bonds) #>  #> Forecast method: ETS(A,Ad,N) #>  #> Model Information: #> ETS(A,Ad,N)  #>  #> Call: #> ets(y = bonds) #>  #>   Smoothing parameters: #>     alpha = 0.9999  #>     beta  = 0.0954  #>     phi   = 0.8026  #>  #>   Initial states: #>     l = 5.3252  #>     b = 0.5934  #>  #>   sigma:  0.2428 #>  #>      AIC     AICc      BIC  #> 256.5383 257.2502 273.5082  #>  #> Error measures: #>                       ME      RMSE       MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set -0.01622111 0.2378765 0.1969524 -0.3276314 3.611147 0.2440042 #>                   ACF1 #> Training set 0.1426552 #>  #> Forecasts: #>          Point Forecast    Lo 80    Hi 80 #> Jun 2004       4.744090 4.432953 5.055227 #> Jul 2004       4.779505 4.322348 5.236661 #> Aug 2004       4.807928 4.229691 5.386165 #> Sep 2004       4.830740 4.144568 5.516913 #> Oct 2004       4.849049 4.063834 5.634264 #> Nov 2004       4.863744 3.986280 5.741207 #> Dec 2004       4.875537 3.911379 5.839695 #> Jan 2005       4.885002 3.838871 5.931134 #> Feb 2005       4.892599 3.768607 6.016591 #> Mar 2005       4.898696 3.700482 6.096910 #> Apr 2005       4.903589 3.634409 6.172770 #> May 2005       4.907517 3.570303 6.244731 #> Jun 2005       4.910669 3.508080 6.313258 #> Jul 2005       4.913199 3.447657 6.378740 #> Aug 2005       4.915229 3.388948 6.441510 #> Sep 2005       4.916859 3.331869 6.501848 #> Oct 2005       4.918166 3.276338 6.559995 #> Nov 2005       4.919216 3.222273 6.616159 #> Dec 2005       4.920058 3.169596 6.670521 #> Jan 2006       4.920735 3.118233 6.723236 #> Feb 2006       4.921277 3.068112 6.774442 #> Mar 2006       4.921713 3.019167 6.824258 #> Apr 2006       4.922062 2.971334 6.872791 #> May 2006       4.922343 2.924552 6.920134 autoplot(forecast_bonds) +   labs(     title = "US 10-year bond yields",     x = "Year",     y = "Percentage per annum",     caption = "Fig. 2.1a"   )

title: Using expsmooth: worked examples
code: fit_usnetelec <- ets(usnetelec) forecast_usnetelec <- forecast(fit_usnetelec, level = 80) summary(forecast_usnetelec) #>  #> Forecast method: ETS(M,A,N) #>  #> Model Information: #> ETS(M,A,N)  #>  #> Call: #> ets(y = usnetelec) #>  #>   Smoothing parameters: #>     alpha = 0.9999  #>     beta  = 0.2191  #>  #>   Initial states: #>     l = 254.9338  #>     b = 38.3125  #>  #>   sigma:  0.0259 #>  #>      AIC     AICc      BIC  #> 634.0437 635.2682 644.0803  #>  #> Error measures: #>                    ME     RMSE      MAE       MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set 1.162583 52.00363 36.77721 0.2629582 1.942062 0.5211014 #>                     ACF1 #> Training set 0.006113498 #>  #> Forecasts: #>      Point Forecast    Lo 80    Hi 80 #> 2004       3900.329 3770.801 4029.857 #> 2005       3952.650 3747.279 4158.022 #> 2006       4004.972 3725.589 4284.355 #> 2007       4057.293 3701.885 4412.701 #> 2008       4109.614 3674.968 4544.259 #> 2009       4161.935 3644.367 4679.503 #> 2010       4214.256 3609.881 4818.632 #> 2011       4266.577 3571.428 4961.726 #> 2012       4318.898 3528.985 5108.812 #> 2013       4371.220 3482.552 5259.888 autoplot(forecast_usnetelec) +   labs(     title = "US net electricity generation",     x = "Year",     y = "Billion kwh",     caption = "Fig. 2.1b"   )

title: Using expsmooth: worked examples
code: fit_ukcars <- ets(ukcars) forecast_ukcars <- forecast(fit_ukcars, level = 80) summary(forecast_ukcars) #>  #> Forecast method: ETS(A,N,A) #>  #> Model Information: #> ETS(A,N,A)  #>  #> Call: #> ets(y = ukcars) #>  #>   Smoothing parameters: #>     alpha = 0.6199  #>     gamma = 1e-04  #>  #>   Initial states: #>     l = 314.2568  #>     s = -1.7579 -44.9601 21.1956 25.5223 #>  #>   sigma:  25.9302 #>  #>      AIC     AICc      BIC  #> 1277.752 1278.819 1296.844  #>  #> Error measures: #>                    ME     RMSE      MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set 1.313884 25.23244 20.17907 -0.1570979 6.629003 0.6576259 #>                    ACF1 #> Training set 0.02573334 #>  #> Forecasts: #>         Point Forecast    Lo 80    Hi 80 #> 2005 Q2       427.4885 394.2576 460.7195 #> 2005 Q3       361.3329 322.2353 400.4305 #> 2005 Q4       404.5358 360.3437 448.7280 #> 2006 Q1       431.8154 383.0568 480.5741 #> 2006 Q2       427.4885 374.5571 480.4200 #> 2006 Q3       361.3329 304.5345 418.1313 #> 2006 Q4       404.5358 344.1174 464.9542 #> 2007 Q1       431.8154 367.9809 495.6500 autoplot(forecast_ukcars) +   labs(     title = "UK passenger motor vehicle production",     x = "Year",     y = "Thousands of cars",     caption = "Fig. 2.1c"   )

title: Authors and Citation
text: Rob Hyndman. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Justin Carmody. Contributor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Hyndman RJ (2025). expsmooth: Data sets "Exponential smoothing: state space approach" Hyndman, Koehler, Ord Snyder (Springer, 2008). R package version 2.3.0.9000, https://pkg.robjhyndman.com/expsmooth/. Hyndman RJ, Koehler AB, Ord JK, Snyder RD (2008). Exponential smoothing: state space approach. Springer.
code: @Manual{,   title = {expsmooth: Data sets from "Exponential smoothing: a state space approach" by Hyndman, Koehler, Ord and Snyder (Springer, 2008)},   author = {Rob J Hyndman},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 2.3.0.9000},   url = {https://pkg.robjhyndman.com/expsmooth/}, } @Book{,   title = {Exponential smoothing: a state space approach},   author = {Rob J Hyndman and Anne B Koehler and J Keith Ord and Ralph D Snyder},   year = {2008},   publisher = {Springer}, }

text: bivariate time series

title: US gasoline prices — gasprice
text: https://robjhyndman.com/expsmooth/. series obtained US Energy Information Administration website https://www.eia.gov.

title: US gasoline prices — gasprice
code: par(mar = c(5, 4, 2, 5)) plot(gasprice[, 1],   xlab = "Year", ylab = "Average retail price per gallon (dollars)",   main = "Gasoline and oil prices" ) par(new = TRUE) plot(gasprice[, 2], col = "blue", xaxt = "n", yaxt = "n", xlab = "", ylab = "") axis(4) mtext("Spot price per barrel (dollars)", side = 4, line = 3) legend("topleft",   col = c("black", "blue"), lty = 1,   legend = c("Ave retail price of gasoline", "Spot price of WTI oil") )
